Authors:
Jean-Marc Torres, Thiago Dias Barbosa, Marcos Junji
Kitaura, Adriano Spielmann, Aline Pedroso Lorenz
Title:
Two new species of Sticta from the Brazilian Cerrado
(Brazilian savanna)
Keywords:
Cyanolichens, DNA barcoding, Cerrado, Brazil, new
taxa
Abstract:
Sticta, the most diverse genus of the Lobarioideae
(Ascomycota: Peltigeraceae), contains species easily recognized by the
presence of genuine cyphellae on the lower cortex of the thallus. From
specimens of Sticta collected during field trips in typical cerrado
vegetation of Central Brazil, two new species were found, Sticta
bitomentosa and S. porella; and they are described in detail in this
study, including morphological, anatomical, and molecular analyses based
on the nuITS region. The two new taxa belong to one of the major Sticta
clades, which contains mostly New World species. This work shows that
the cerrado, a global biodiversity hotspot located in the center of
South America, could contain a great diversity of new species of
lichenized fungi.
